explanation:
strerror — The code calls strerror(-error) and strerror(errno). The MISRA rule applies to string.h functions; to judge whether this use can access out-of-bounds memory we must know the documented behaviour of strerror for (possibly negative or out-of-range) errnum values and whether it can return a pointer that could lead to unsafe reads.

errno — mlock failure handling uses strerror(errno). To determine whether the argument passed to strerror is valid and whether errno can produce an out-of-range effect, the analysis needs the semantics/definition of the errno variable in the environment.

metal_map — The code calls metal_map and then passes -error to strerror on failure. We must know metal_map's return-value convention (e.g., returns negative errno or positive error codes) to determine whether passing -error to strerror yields a valid/non-negative errnum or an out-of-range value that could provoke unsafe behaviour.

mlock — The code tests mlock return value and calls strerror(errno) on failure. We need mlock's failure semantics (i.e., whether it sets errno and what values) to confirm that the strerror argument is valid.

metal_log — The calls to metal_log include format specifiers "%s" with the pointer returned by strerror. To fully assess whether this use can cause out-of-bounds accesses we must inspect metal_log's implementation/format-handling (it may call printf/vsnprintf or other string routines) to see if it treats the string pointer safely (expects NUL-terminated strings, copies into fixed buffers, or calls any string.h functions internally).
